string.name: addplant_eggplant_mini_desc
string.p: Commonly used as a vegetable in dishes, but is, scientifically, actually, a fruit. The plant is one of the many vegetables you can grow in your garden, however, it is very sensitive to cold. Raw eggplant is composed of 92% water, 6% carbs, and 1% protein.

string.name: mats_eggplant_desc
string.p: The fruit is widely used in cooking. As a member of the genus Solanum, it is related to the tomato and the potato. Eggplant is one of the many vegetables you can grow in your garden, but the plant is very sensitive to cold. Raw eggplant is composed of 92% water, 6% carbohydrates, 1% protein, and negligible fat.

resources.string: Large pot for mature eggplant (20 Liter capacity at least, preferably clay pot)
Growing your slips (Day 0) \n\t1. Clean the sweet potato and split it in half (or large sections).
\t2. Put them in a container with half of the potato submerged in water.
\t3. Put it in a window ledge or anywhere warm (e.g. on top of a radiator).
\t4. tObserve if the slips are 6-9 inches long everyday within the first 6 weeks of planting.
\t5. Twist the slips off from the potato
\t6. Transfer the slip to a shallow bowl with half the stem submerged in water.
\t7. Observe if the roots have grown about an inch and keep the water fresh (few days).
Transferring the Slips \n\t8. Make sure the soil is loose

\t9. Using a small hand trowel, dig a hole about 4" or 5" deep and 3" wide. Place one slip in each hole with the roots pointing down. Position the slip so that the bottom half will be covered with dirt while the top half with all of the new leaves is above ground.
\t10. Carefully cover the hole with soil and gently press (to remove remaining air pockets).
Growing the potatoes \n\t11. Water until the surrounding dirt is wet. Stop watering before your mound starts to erode.
\t15. Water at least once a week (70-150 days).
\t16. Check the soil everyday. Water the soil if it is dry.
Harvesting \n\t17. Observe if leaves start to yellow(everyday).
\t18. Use a spading fork to dig tubers on a sunny day when the soil is dry.
2.\tPrepare soil. Mix 2 parts potting soil, 1 part sand. Mix a little compost and 5-10-5 fertilizer.
4.\tStart indoors, temperature must be 12.8 C or higher. Fill your small pots or trays with the potting mix.
5.\tPoke a ½ inch (1.25 cm) hole in the center of each pot or tray. Place 2 seeds in each hole. Cover them afterwards, just lightly drop the soil over the seeds, don’t pack it in.
6.\tSet the pots or trays out on a warm, sunny windowsill. Ensure that the window receives at least 8 hours of sunlight a day.
7.\tWater the seeds every day. Don’t create puddles of water on top of your soil but prevent the soil from drying out.
8.\tOnce the seedlings sprout two sets of leaves, snip out the weaker seedling, do not yank the weaker seedling out.
9.\tPrepare for transplanting once the plant reaches at least ½ foot (15.25 cm) in height.
10.\tSet up the supporting stakes in the permanent pot.
11.\tFill the permanent pot with the potting medium
12.\tDig a hole in the center of the pot that is as deep and wide as the container the seedlings are currently planted in.
13.\tRemove the seedling from its container and place it into the new pot. It is easier to transplant a wet and compact soil than dry, crumbly soil.
14. Place the pot in a sunny location.
15.\tWater the plant daily. You might need to water additionally if the weather is hot and dry
16.\tAdd liquid fertilizer once every 2 weeks. Make sure you add fertilizer after watering the soil, don’t add fertilizer on dry soil.
17.\tTie the eggplant to the support to promote upward growth.
